EmailTemplate.subject: December News: Announcing Spring Framework 4.0
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
DECEMBER 2013 <https://spring.io/blog/2013/12/06/webinar-introduction-to-spring-framework-4-0> Announcing Spring Framework 4.0 Pivotal is excited to celebrate the first major release of Spring since Spring Framework 3.0 released in 2009! We don’t change the major version number lightly, but we think that once you try Spring Framework 4.0 for yourself, you’ll see why we did. If you are hungry for the details, make sure to join none other than Juergen Hoeller for the Spring Framework 4.0 launch webinar on Jan 9th, 2014 <https://spring.io/blog/2013/12/06/webinar-introduction-to-spring-framework-4-0>. In the meantime, you can get the first level of detail by reading the press release <http://www.gopivotal.com/press-center/12122013-spring-4>, and Adrian Colyer’s Blog Article: Announcing the Spring Framework 4.0 GA release <http://spring.io/blog/2013/12/12/announcing-spring-framework-4-0-ga-release>. We’ve got lots of new videos, guides, demos, webinars, and assets in celebration of the release, make sure to check the new “featured guides” section of the newsletter. Also, keep an eye out for more launch content between now and Jan 9, 2014. Click here <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qoA_MAvM7p8> to listen to what developers are saying - and we look forward to your feedback on the release!
Happy Holidays, The Spring Team Register <https://spring.io/blog/2013/12/06/webinar-introduction-to-spring-framework-4-0> Import the new Getting Started Guides into STS People love the new getting started guides on http://spring.io/ <http://spring.io>. Since version 3.4.0 of the Spring Tool Suite there is an extremely easy way to use those guides directly from within the IDE. A new wizard (New -> Spring -> Import Spring Getting Started Content) lets you search and choose the guide you would like to import into your workspace. As a result the wizard imports the project(s) directly into your workspace and opens up the webpage of the guide for a detailed description right within your IDE. In addition to that you can choose whether to import the project in its final state (fully implemented) and/or in a starter state, from where you can go and implement the feature yourself while following the guide description. Click here <https://spring.io/blog/2013/12/10/build-a-robust-rest-ful-web-service-in-less-than-6-minutes> to see a demo of it in action! Being @Lazy with Spring Framework 4 Spring 4 has expanded the applications for the @Lazy <http://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/context/annotation/Lazy.html> annotation. In addition to its role for component initialization, this annotation may also be placed on injection points marked with @Autowired <http://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/beans/factory/annotation/Autowired.html> or @Inject <http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/inject/Inject.html>: In that context, it leads to the creation of a lazy-resolution proxy for all affected dependencies, as an alternative to using ObjectFactory <http://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/beans/factory/ObjectFactory.html> factories or Provider <http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/inject/Provider.html> providers. So, given a bean dataSource defined with prototype scope, the following injections are all identical and all lazily create a new DataSource only when the variables are used (e.g, when the injected variable itself is accessed by code) or when the factory method is called: ``` // possible today with JSR 330 @Inject Provider dataSourceProvider; // possible today with core Spring @Autowired ObjectFactory<DataSource> dataSourceObjectFactory; // Spring 4's @Lazy and @Autowired @Lazy @Autowired DataSource autowiredDataSource; // Spring 4's @Lazy and JSR 330 @Inject @Lazy @Inject DataSource injectedDataSource; ``` I think the @Lazy syntax is far more expressive, and less intrusive. You'll find complete descriptions of all these books, along with sale chapters and other resource, at manning.com <http://www.manning.com>. Introduction to Spring Framework 4.0 Speaker: Juergen Hoeller
The Spring Framework re-invented enterprise Java in the last decade. Together with the rest of the upcoming Spring IO micro platform, a new Spring Framework generation will power the next decade of JVM-based innovation.
Join Juergen Hoeller to learn about Spring Framework 4.0, its refined annotation-based component and configuration model, and how it relates to Java 8, Java EE 7, Groovy, WebSockets, as well as Spring Boot and Spring Integration. Europe
